38779760.review:
I've left this review spoiler-free, in case you still want to give it a shot...? Eh.

I had been putting this game off for a while and since it was on sale, I decided to just go for it and get it, despite the negative reviews revolving the main character which I unfortunately have to agree with now,

Aesthetically, this game is very pretty. The horror elements were quirky and it had style, although it wasn't particularly frightening.
Gameplay-wise, it may as well play itself. The puzzles were pretty easy, you're not left there figuring out what to do. However, there was a part in Act 3 where you have to repeat the whole segment over and over again - amounting to about four times...? All for the purpose of just small differences in between. The repetitiveness in that part was honestly just annoying and it would have been better if they just extended Act 3 rather than making you play it several times. I was enjoying the game up until Act 3, which was frustrating and just boring if I'm honest.

I was hoping the ending would make up for it. It didn't. Not only did it not answer any questions, but it just confused me even more. You're given no answers and then it's over.
It could have been better if the main character had more... character? She's so UNRESPONSIVE to everything. She doesn't have any reaction to the weird things she encounters, all you can get out of her really is just '...' Literally.
I mean, if the point of the story is that it's open to interpretation, I get that, but combining the fact that the character is so deadpan and that the ending gives you no answers (you don't have much to speculate really), you don't get any satisfaction from completing the game.


TL;DR: short and kinda sweet game (until Act 3). It's pretty, but ultimately boring and dissapointing due to the main character's lack of character and bad ending.

38433552.review:
I'm not entirely sure how I've been left feeling about this game...

At first, everything was gripping. The main character is a little "meh" - her reactions to all of the weird and unusual happenings don't really make any sense, which loses a little of the immersion for me.

I really, really love the character design and the score - this was a bit thumbs up for me!! I only wish there was a little more depth to the story, perhaps covering why the characters are the way they are (e.g. Sphinx, Babyhead).

The story was...compelling at first, but by Act III I was just bored. The game gets very dull, as you're forced to repeat the same (somewhat lengthy) sequence over and over and over...you can't complete the game without doing so.

It's a beautiful game, and it's only 2 hours long. If you're looking for a game with some mildy complex puzzles and a shallow story, this is what you're after. I wouldn't recommend this to those who want story or horror-shock.

Overall, not what I was expecting, but it's less than £2 for 2hrs play. It had a lot of potential, but Act III let it down.

38393169.review:
Stray Cat Crossing is a niche game targeted at fans of RPG Maker cult games such as The Witch's House, Ib, OFF and Ao Oni. 
The art and visual design is perfectly executed throughout the entire game; it's probably some of the best art you'll see in an RPG Maker project. However, it lacks substance in the crucial areas which made those games so memorable: story and originality. The writing is poorly executed and, although the game is rife with metaphorical imagery, none of it feels really meaningful. The beautifully rendered characters are not compelling or developed in interesting ways which make you care about them. As a fan of these types of games, I personally enjoyed Stray Cat Crossing for its art and not much else, and I feel that ultimately it was a bland experience.

36181037.review:
A short horror game made with RPG Maker. Come to think of it, it's kinda weird that this engine was originally made for RPGs, but that most of the best games made with it are horror adventure games.

Although the beginning feels very horror-ish (red screen tones, jump scares, you get the idea), as the game progresses and you learn more about the plot, the horror elements get less frequent the game gets more surreal.

+ The pixel art is great, from environments to sprites and characters portraits. The music is also pretty good. It's rare to hear post-rock in video games.

+ It manages to tell an interesting story in a couple of hours, while still leaving a bit open to interpretation. The characters are very unique (particularly the Japanese goat-mom-witch).

+ / - The gameplay is pretty standard for this kind of game (mostly puzzles, and one chase sequence). The last part can feel a bit repetitive since it involves some kind of sequence loop (I love this kind of stuff, but apparently I'm the only one who does).

- The trailer features some nice animations but sadly none of those are in the game. Although the jumpscares are actually quite well-animated.

7/10 Short (like that review), original (not like that review), cheap (I'll let you decide if it applies to that review). If you like things like Yume Nikki, you'll probably like it (the game, not my review).

36085004.review:
Stray Cat Crossing é um jogo de terror e com gráficos pixelados, combinação muito comum em jogos de RPG Maker. Sem muita inovação no quesito jogabilidade, o jogo se apoia na possibilidade de passar uma profunda mensagem pela história que se desenvolve enquanto você resolve puzzles. O jogo usa um sistema de "complicado no início e respostas no final", que vez ou outra ainda pode confundir aqueles que o jogam sem prestar muita atenção.

[h1]Jogabilidade[/h1]

Como dito anteriormente, não é nenhum pioneiro em termos de jogabilidade. Você controla uma personagem em até quatro direções e interage com objetos em pró de resolver os enigmas que são lhe impostos para avançar pelo jogo.
Rápido e prático, você no primeiro minuto de jogo já entende todos os comandos e consegue então desfrutar da história que será contada de uma maneira interessante.

Os quebra cabeças são fáceis, não foram desenvolvidos de modo que seja necessário um pensar muito aprofundado do jogador para a solução. A maior dificuldade imposta (de maneira precária) é em alguns momentos questionar da função dos objetos que fica muito discreto, exigindo maior exploração do cenário e contando menos com seus olhos.
Seus puzzles podem ser facilmente resolvidos com spammar de botões em todos objetos que é possível interagir no cenário, o que é um ponto negativo para esse tipo de jogo.

Não existem muitas 'cenas' de ação, mas elas são feitas de uma maneira [b]tediosa[/b] e [b]preguiçosa[/b]. Movimentos rápidos sem muita espera do jogador entender o que acontece inicialmente, acaba que exige repetição de inúmeras vezes algo que poderia ser feito em uma ou duas tentativas, já que esse tipo de 'desafio' se torna massante e não desafiador.

[b]Repetição[/b] talvez seja a palavra que defina certos aspectos e puzzles do jogo, talvez feito para aumentar a vida útil curta de Stray Cat Crossing. Em alguns momentos, infelizmente acontece de você repetir a mesma coisa diversas vezes de maneiras diferentes para conseguir prosseguir, deixando a jogabilidade cansativa e tediosa.

[h1]História e enredo[/h1]

A história conta sobre uma personagem que estava no meio de uma estrada, com a intenção de voltar para casa, até que encontra uma garotinha perdida chamada Cat, que havia fugido de casa. Ao aquecê-la com seu cachecol, a protagonista então leva a criança até sua casa, mas acaba se esquecendo de pegar de volta o seu importante cachecol, então invadindo a casada garota em busca da mesma para pegá-lo de volta. A partir desse momento, coisas estranhas e assustadoras passam a acontecer em volta de nossa heroína, que ao mesmo tempo que quer ir embora, quer também seu cachecol de volta.

O enredo se conta através dos patéticos puzzles impostos pelo jogo, de uma maneira extremamente discreta que ao longo que você avança a história, vai passando a entender as situações que os personagens se encontram e representam, apesar de ser bem fácil deixar algo passar e ficar sem respostas no final. Esse jeito de contar a história é muito incrível quando bem explorado, e até que foi bem feito nesse jogo, apesar de tudo só passar a fazer um maior sentido próximo ao final.

[h1]Trilha Sonora[/h1]

Ponto positivo para essa seção também. As músicas são curtas, cerca de 1 minuto cada uma. Abusam principalmente de piano e dão uma atmosfera mais melancólica à situação, cumprindo seu trabalho de maneira excelente para o gênero que foi composta.

Suas faixas mais animadas/calmas são [b]realmente boas[/b], provavelmente as melhores, o que é algo inesperado quando se trata desse tipo de jogo.

[h1]Visuais[/h1]

Pixelart bem detalhado, cores usadas com precisão para cenários mais sombrios e um estilo visual único. Uma beleza de maneira especial, que destaca o jogo de sua própria maneira.

Suas 'cutscenes' são muito boas, apesar de rápidas. Animações em um estilo mais detalhado que usa e abusa da falta de cores, dando uma imersão ao universo aterrorizante do jogo. 

O problema que o jogo apresenta são as animações dos sprites, principalmente as dos personagens se movendo. São travadas, parecendo mecânicas, o que tira boa parte do charme desses visuais belos. Infelizmente uma cruz que o jogo carrega, mas não sendo medonhas a ponto de estragar a experiência por completo.

[h1]Conclusão[/h1]

Preço baixo, história boa e que vai fazer você trabalhar a cabeça um pouco para compreender todos os acontecimentos, usando terror e leves jumpscares para te envolver numa trágica jornada. Não recomendado para pessoas que buscam quebra cabeças complicados, mas sim que querem uma boa história contada em fios embolados, dados para o jogador desembolar e alinhar.

35617620.review:
Игра, которая показала какими красивыми могут быть игры на RPG Maker.

К несчастью, в последнее время пиксель-арт стал стилем разработчиков, не умеющих рисовать. Особенно от этого страдают игры на rpgmaker, который позиционирует себя как программа для не умеющих рисовать, программировать и бог знает чего еще не знающих игроделов. И это печально.
И эта игра всем может показать что такое настоящий пиксель-арт. Все любовно нарисовано, подобрано по стилю и колориту. Каждая комната и локация как просто конфетка. Особенно приятно смотреть на портреты персонажей, этот дизайн и переходы цвета.

Геймплей не так безупречен, но хорош. Плюс - интересные загадки и головоломки. Минус - их мало.
Странный способ начать историю и такой же странный способ ее закончить. Героиня лезет в особняк за потерянным шарфиком игнорируя то, что ее только что не сожрал монстр. Можно списать это на незакрытый гештальт, не знаю. Но меня бы порадовала дополнительная концовка, в которой героиня со словами "в жопу этот шарф" уходит в закат. 
Конец истории представляет из себя временную петлю, которую нужно пройти несколько раз, чтобы добраться до концовки. Было бы хорошо, если бы мы могли бы пройти петлю за раз, но нам бы мешало то, что мы не разбираемся в ситуации. Но нет, мы копим монетки для покупки попкорна, доставая их из гроба. Еще один минус - выполнив неправильную последовательность действий вы застрянете в петле. И это не задумка разработчика, вы просто застревайте, так как все нпс ушли без вас, конец.
Если ищете эпичный сюжет, то не ищите его здесь. Тут история личной трагедии, детских страхов и чувства вины. Он лаконичен и хорош. Из этого сюжета буйным цветом растет символизм всей игры, который достоин отдельной похвалы.
Кстати, дождитесь конца титров.
За такую цену игра просто подарок. Берите не пожалеете.

35599496.review:
Wow! An emphatic recommendation from me.

Let's get the negatives out of the way first -- it's short, it has some issues with crashes (they don't stop you from completing the game), and gameplay is limited to fetching things and chatting with things, with attempts to add variety missing the mark.

For another game those might be dealbreakers, but Stray Cat Crossing isn't about the mechanics. It's about the spooky world and demented characters which have sprung from the minds of its creators, and in every way that it needs to immerse you in that world, it succeeds.

The soundtrack is good -- each track is short, tight, distinct, and enhances the game's atmosphere.

The plot has its fair share of memorable moments. It's convoluted but considering the nature of the world we are visiting, maybe that's just what it should be. It has inspired numerous theories and speculation among fans.

But the artwork, Wow, this is some of the best pixel art I've seen in years. It approaches the level of the top titles of the 16 bit era. Comparisons with Chrono Trigger come to mind, which is simply astounding considering the dream team behind the art of CT!

And we can't overlook the price, which is only a few bucks on Steam at the time of writing, so it's hard to say you aren't getting value for money.

Above all I think it's the character concepts which make this game a must play. It's rare to come across characters this weird, creepy and creative in any title of any budget. Stray Cat Crossing ultimately serves as a showcase for the eclectic imaginations of its authors, and in this regard it's a complete and unique success.

The other comparison I couldn't help making was to the Wadjet Eye P&C titles I've been playing recently, some of which are real works of art. If Jurlo and JetPackGone polished the weak points in their output and produced a full-length adventure game with a surreal horror atmosphere reminiscent of Stray Cat's, we could be looking at a one-of-a-kind masterpiece.

If summary if you have a little nostalgia for the heydays of 16 bit RPGs or adventure games, and you're into creepy atmospheric horror, and you won't rage when the game occasionally crashes or shows a rough edge, Stray Cat is a must play.

34865330.review:
[quote]“If cats looked like frogs we'd realize what nasty, cruel little bastards¹ they are. Style. That's what people remember.”
[i]― Terry Pratchett, Lords and Ladies[/i][/quote]

In one word, [i]Stray Cat Crossing[/i] is "stylish".

[h1]Foreword[/h1]
This would be a [b]"NEUTRAL" REVIEW[/b], if the option were available. Since Steam, in its infinite wisdom, strips us all of the choice, take this as a recommendation as weak as tea deprived of its proper infusion time.

Special thanks to my friend "Lion" for joining me on beating this one. The frustrating parts would have been enraging without someone to share the annoyance with, and the theories would have drifted away without further discussion.

[h1]General Impressions[/h1]
[i]Stray Cat Crossing[/i] is a roughly 4-hour long RPGMaker horror game. As such, it has inherent limitations, which it sometimes overcomes and sometimes falls prey to. It outdoes itself in terms of character design, mood, art and music, but falls short when it comes to game mechanics, pacing and a memorable story. 

With that being said, what [i]Stray Cat Crossing[/i] outdoes itself in, many have outdone themselves in before it – and many will continue to do so after it. While this title may stand out among its RPGMaker siblings as pretty and plesant sounding, it is also the child that screams nonsense at the table over and over again when everyone is just trying to dine in peace.

[i]Stray Cat Crossing[/i] doesn't understand when to elaborate its thoughts and when to show, rather than tell. Despite having eye-catching displays of its musings, it doesn't know [b]when[/b] to voice them. An even bigger crime is that its silences come in packs, causing more discomfort than wonder. 

Above of all, it doesn't understand that decent game mechanics should [b]always[/b] exclude repeating the same tasks over and over again through unskippable cutscenes.

In short, while [i]Stray Cat Crossing[/i] succeeds in things that its genre isn't renowned for, it fails at a core aspect of good storytelling, be it a bedtime story or an intricate centuries-old tale: it fails at being memorable.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
[i]Stray Cat Crossing[/i]'s biggest fault is being a niche game. It appeals to a specific kind of gamer and, if you're not lucky enough to find yourself in that category, its shortcomings will shine brighter than its gems. If, however, you find yourself inside the specific frame this game was painted for, its faults will hopefully simply be a speck of a drifting ship, lost in a sea of aesthetic graphics and darn good music.

I recommend [i]Stray Cat Crossing[/i] to seekers of good art and music, that enjoy their fair share of words, don't mind wonky puzzles and can handle some repetition. I don't recommend it to anyone that doesn't see themselves clearly in the previous sentence.

[i]EDIT: ¹Bast.ards. Yes, Steam, censor Pratchett. Speaks volumes of your taste.[/i]

34669867.review:
[h1]A chilling, little horror game hiding behind an innocent yet deceptive title.[/h1]

This game was gifted to me by a friend. I absolutely loved the dark and twisted atmosphere. It hooked me in right from the beginning and kept me wanting to know more after each turn in the story. Not knowing anything about our main character we jump right in; the search for our beloved scarf. 

[h1]Positives[/h1]
-A fairly short but intense story that makes you question what is happening constantly.
-Unique Artwork. Creepy and cute are the only two words to describe it.
-Wonderful music to go along with the dark atmosphere.
-Puzzles. Challenging enough to make you think but not frustrating to the point of distracting from the story.
-I love the way the save feature was integrated into the game. 
-Playtime is decent for the price. 

[h1]Negatives (Subjective)[/h1]
-Game crashed for me quite frequently in the beginning. Not sure if a bug or isolated event.
-Default resolution is miniscule, making it full screen distorted it. Again, not sure if it’s just my PC and the way it was presented on my screen. 
-Music is nice, but with that being said, it could get a bit repetitive when you're stuck on a puzzle.
-Accidently made dialogue choices by hitting enter too many times to make the text scroll faster.

Definitely worth the money if you're up for a decent story, interesting characters, incredible creepiness and a handful of jump scares. 

[i]One question though. Why was the nutcracker so afraid of the egg? No wait, perhaps some questions are best left unanswered.[/i]

34173329.review:
"Stray Cat Crossing" jest krótkim psychologicznym horrorem o złożonej i zdumiewająco lirycznej fabule. Bohaterka historii, wędrując bezcelowo pustą autostradą, spotyka młodą dziewczynkę o imieniu Cat. Ten mały zbieg okoliczności sprawia, że obie udają się w miejsce, o którym bardzo chciały zapomnieć.

Ciężko streścić fabułę gry, w której praktycznie każdy element jest kluczowy dla jej historii. Obrazy na ścianach, stare, brudne meble, popękane lustra, zakurzone regały na książki - każdy z tych elementów ma swoją historię i jest nacechowany ogromną ilością informacji, które z początku wydają się nie mieć sensu, lecz po ukończeniu gry stają się logiczne, wręcz oczywiste. Klimat gry powalił mnie na łopatki. Dawno nie czułem tak mocnego dyskomfortu, ogrywając jakąkolwiek produkcję. Mroczna, pikselowa grafika, mrożąca krew w żyłach ścieżka dźwiękowa, niepokojące przerywniki filmowe i szpetota opisanego świata sprawiają, że gracz nie czuje się bezpiecznie, rozszyfrowując kolejne zagadki i poznając dalsze losy bohaterki gry. "Stray Cat Crossing" to górnolotna produkcja, to jej groteskowe zabarwienie sprawia, że włosy jeżą się graczowi na karku. Horror w czystej postaci. Przygoda, która na długo pozostaje w pamięci.

Podsumowując, "Stray Cat Crossing" jest prawdziwym arcydziełem. Rozgrywka trwa niecałe dwie godziny, ale gra jest zdecydowanie warta swojej ceny. Historia nie jest sztucznie przeciągana: każde zadanie, miejsce, każda postać - wszystko wydaje się być świetnie przemyślane i zaprojektowane. Polecam produkt każdej osobie, która ceni sobie głębię fabularną w ogrywanych tytułach.

33053572.review:
I definitely recommend this game. 

At €2.99 original price (although I've never seen it go on sale), you get an almost 3 hour game that is creative and easy on the eyes. The story is deep and contains a fair share of twists. Some you see coming, others you don't. 

I usually understand confusing stories immediately, but a number of things weren't so obvious to me at first. After watching a 9 minute explanation of the game on youtube, though, I got all the hidden messages. I'm sure I would have picked up on everything if I played through it again, anyway. The story has a number of twists and hidden messages that make it quite deep. It's sad, too, to put it lightly. Some people say they cried at the end. The script was surprisingly powerful in that regard, and the sad parts were caused by something rather intense. Hidden messages and metaphors are found constantly in this game, but it's hard to appreciate them on the first playthrough, giving that all the knots are tied together and everything starts making sense only in the end. Until you reach the last "level", the game is an abstract piece of art with hidden meanings you don't understand and can not truly appreciate, and that is why Stray Cat Crossing is worth at least a second playthrough, even though it does not have any achievements. 

I would say that my only complaint with this game is that the last "level" is very repetitive. This is not accidental, and the repetitive aspect is explained and justified well within the story. That said, it doesn't make it any more fun to do the same thing, and read the same dialogue over and over. Something I really liked up until that point was the fluidity of the game, and that I never felt like any part was dragging on until then. Then it dragged on big time. 

Anyway, I don't want to end on a bad note, since I really did enjoy this game and I'm glad I forked out the €2.99 for this experience. It's not spectacular, but it's very well worth it.

31310469.review:
This particular cat is a little on the fence, as far as this game goes. On one hand, it's rather lovingly and competently scored and animated, with its own crazy little "Alice in Wonderland" style - as cliche as that is. The downside, speaking of which, would have to be the cliches. The story takes the path traveled over and over again. [spoiler]At the start of almost any horror/horror-light indie game, the question I always half-jokingly ask myself is, "Okay, what wrongdoing is it going to turn out the protagonist is inexplicably amnesiac about this time?" This game was yet another time I easily won that little bet with myself.[/spoiler] It features essentially a very simple, even mundane, story, and simply slops buckets of symbolism (and a fair amount of distracting nonsense) over it until it's sufficiently thickly coated to obscure the rather shallow real plot beneath all the whimsy. No one is really a "character" in this game. Even down to the protagonist, every individual is more of an archetype filling a pseudo-horror-game storytelling cliche slot, rather than a true personality.

The puzzles are maybe a little too easy, aside from one that's simply obtuse and another that's frustratingly repetitive. Yet, for all these complaints, I can't say I didn't enjoy making my way through the game, or that I wasn't impressed by its presentational flair - even if the tiny animated sequences, a real highlight of the early game, just peter out after a while. Even considering its brevity, at its $3 price point I think it's fair to offer a lukewarm recommendation.

31264025.review:
Stray Cat Crossing è la prima storia a tema horror psicologico che ho affrontato e ne sono rimasto piacevolmente colpito.

TRAMA 
L'inizio del gioco è abbastanza banale : Vestiremo il ruolo di TIZIA (una ragazza il cui nome almeno inizialmente ci è ignoto) e, in una fredda giornata, troveremo una bambina scappata di casa. Dopo averle dato la nostra sciarpa e averla rassicurata la riporteremo indietro. Solo dopo averlo fatto però ci accorgeremo di non esserci fatti ridare la sciarpa, a cui TIZIA è tanto legata.
 Sarà in quel momento che ci decideremo ad entrare nella villa, e dare inizio così alla nostra avventura ! 
Un leggero senso di ansia e angoscia sarà il nostro fedele compagno di viaggio, in quanto l'abitazione presenterà luoghi misteriosi e tetri abitati da creature magiche o comunque paranormali, particolari nei modi e nei gesti.

Potrebbe non avere apparentemente senso ma, credetemi, tutti gli elementi e gli stessi personaggi fanno da filo conduttore con la bambina e sopratutto con noi stessi. La trama è ben delineata e starà a noi con indizi più o meno espliti ricostruire il nostro passato e la nostra identità.

GAMEPLAY
C'è poco da dire. Dovremo esplorare con cura i diversi scenari proposti e fare molta attenzione a quel che dicono i "mostri". A quel punto ci toccherà risolvere delle puzzle quests, a parer mio non difficili ma gradevoli, essendo più basate su dei dialoghi e azioni da compiere piuttosto che su degli enigmi veri e propri.  

CONCLUSIONE 
+ Soundtrack (orecchiabile e immersiva)
+ Trama... (Mi è piaciuta tantissimo. Più si và avanti e più tutto avrà un senso)
+ I dialoghi (prestate davvero attenzione a questi ultimi. Anche le frasi "buttate lì" hanno un significato importante)
+ Personaggi (possiedono un significato metaforico)
+Ambienti (significato allegorico)

- Breve durata (le ore son volate)
- Puzzle birichini (mi sono bloccato per parecchio tempo un paio di volte a causa di una soluzione non facilmente visibile da un lato e non facilmente intuibile dall'altro)
- ... Trama (proprio a causa dei tantii valori che assumono gli elementi del racconto alcuni frammenti della storia potrebbero non essere del tutto chiari. [u]Saranno comunque presenti[/u] ma devono essere colti dal giocatore, e coglierli tutti non è facile. [spoiler]Non mi erano chiari un paio di punti al termine del gioco ma cercando su internet una bella guida li ho capiti. Sono sì presenti nella storia, semplicemente non erano esposti in maniera ben definita[/spoiler]

Stray Cat Crossing è un titolo che vi consiglio assolutamente di provare. Bello, intrigante e pieno di significato. Ogni personaggio, ogni ambientazione circonda e dà senso alla trama, creando al contempo la trama stessa.

-Al

28976922.review:
Скажу честно, очень не хочется ставить этой маленькой игре-истории «палец вниз», потому что плохой её не назовёшь, но всё же нужно разбавить сплошь положительные отзывы.
Stray Cat Crossing – ещё одна вариация на тему «Алисы в Стране чудес», только без Алисы и без Страны чудес и даже без Зазеркалья. Впрочем, без вариации на тему Синей гусеницы и мыши-сони авторы не удержались.
Все персонажи безумны, а главная героиня в погоне за своим шарфиком напрочь лишена инстинкта самосохранения. Это к вопросу о плюсах, о которых можно прочитать в любой из соседних рецензий на игру. Вообще весь первый акт игры удался на славу, мрачная неуютная атмосфера, строго дозированный чёрный юмор, троллинг игрока предстоящим скримером (которого не будет), несколько неиллюзорных шансов увидеть надпись «The End», означающую преждевременный «гамовер». 
И… Всё, с окончанием первого акта лучшая половина атмосферы из игры улетучивается. Дальше не будет никаких попыток напугать или уничтожить главную героиню. Если первый акт геймплейно представлял собой «пойди-потыкай-принеси» квест, то второй – это уже набор простейших паззлов: поверни стрелки часов, чтоб получился мост на нужный берег; пройди алогично изменяющийся лабиринт; отгадай простую загадку (с двумя подсказками). Добивает школьная задачка про кувшин на 5 литров и на 3. Можно было придумать что-то более оригинальное. Весь второй акт нам намекают на то, что в конце будет «босс», как и в конце первого акта, но никакого «босса» не будет. 
Суть третьего акта в том, чтобы выбраться из временной петли. Здесь нам раскрывают «истинный» сюжет игры, объясняют, что за кашу вообще заварили, кто виноват и что делать. Многие жалуются, что третий акт вынуждает их делать одни и те же действия по 8-20 раз, на деле же для выхода из временной петли потребуется всего 3 или 4 круга. Главное – делать максимум возможных действий.
Итог. Начали за здравие, закончили так себе. Отдельный плюс за точку сохранения, которой тут является вездесущий мальчик с полароидом в руках и выжженными глазами. Первый раз реально жутковато. 
7/10
P.S. От «босса» в конце первого акта сбежать очень просто. Нужно лишь постоянно держать зажатыми стрелку вниз и Shift, а также нажимать без остановки кнопку прыжка. В пропасть героиня не свалится, но прыжки резко увеличивают ее скорость передвижения.

This game is exactly the kind of horror game that I like - not too long, mostly story and atmosphere oreinted, with minimal jumpscares. Seriously, I hate jumpscares, but their infrequent enough in this game that I still really enjoyed it. This game is dark, unsettling, and scary at times, but it is far from your typical hardcore game. For those looking for a true thrill, this is not a game for you. If you're looking for what is basically a "point-and-click" adventure with a horror theme and super dark atmosphere, then I recomend checking this game out. This is not ACTUALLY a point and click - you control your character with the arrow keys and interact by pressing a button on the keyboard (I forgot which one, but that's not important) - but the puzzles in this game operate very similarly.  You explore, find clues and itmes, and use the clues to figure out what to do with the items. Most of the puzzles in this game are quite good, although there are a couple less-than-superb ones as well that are either frustrating or tedious. There is no combat, so the exploration and puzzles make up 100% of the gameplay, but the biggest attraction is the story and atmosphere. 
The story is wonderful. The game is one big metaphorical mystery that all ties together at the end, and I quite enjoyed it. This game absolutely worth playing just for the story. It's not too long (about 2-3 hours), so there's no excuse not to find time to experience this atmospheric horror story game. Highly recomended for anyone who likes dark short stories and doesn't mind puzzles.

POSITIVES
-Most gorgeous looking RPG maker style game I have seen to date-
-Elements of horror which had me sufficiently spooked-
-Wonderful depth, lots of metaphors behind the story as you play-
-Almost cried at the end-
-Some really nice music tracks, I sat for a couple minutes in some areas just enojying-

-Atmosphere in general-
-Bite sized gameplay-
-Some really sweet moments in dialogue-
-Covers themes of guilt and regret excellently-
-I can't speak for price as I was gifted this game, but I believe that it's worth the buy as it's not very expensive-

NEGATIVE

24167175.review:
So I just finished this game today, after spending only 3 hours but it felt like a very complete experience, and I don't particularly feel it needed to be longer. 

Overall I recommend the game, though this comes with some caveats. I won't call them pros and cons since I think a lot of my gripes are more personal in nature and I enjoyed the experience. 

Stuff I enjoyed. 
[list]
    [*]Beautiful settings, and characters - The designers worked hard and it's surreal and jaunty. Initially I feared the game might be yet another play on the Wonderland theme that while interesting, I see too much of to care for these days (seriously, guys, try re-imagining another work of classical fiction for a change). Yet, in spite of the presence of at least one giant caterpillar and exceedingly creepy twins, it didn't feel 'Alice in Wonderland' at all. 
    [*]General creepiness - if that were what this game was going for alone, then it definitely succeeded. 
    [*]Decent writing and concepts with some genuinely unnerving moments. 
    [*]Good for players looking for a shorter, condensed storytelling experience which is not too difficult in terms of puzzles. 
[/list]

Things to Address. 
[list]
    [*]Difficult controls. The character movements feel "floaty" and sometimes jerky and could do with being tightened up a bit. The game is controller compatible, but there was no option to adjust the configuration, so I was left attempting to press the key to run (Y) and the key to jump (A) at the same time which made me feel like a contortionist. I switched to the keyboard, which helped, but there were still issues... 
    [*] That. First. Running. Challenge. One of the earliest tests in the game... involves running away from something, This took an obscene amount of time to get the hang of. The game's sensitive controls were the major sticking point. 
    [*]It's... not really horror to me. It's surreal and weird, but I'm the kind of person who has conniptions waiting at a strange drive thru at 8 pm and *I* didn't feel unnerved, which ought to tell you something. If you're looking for an intense horror experience you won't get it here. Unless you have a phobia of dolls or mutant insects. Then you're kind of screwed. 
   [*]Lacklustre puzzles. There were not many of them - understandable, but disappointing, and those that were there were very easy to figure out.I understand that many would not consider that a bad thing, but I feel it might be disappointing for some players who were expecting a more genuine challenge. 
[/list]

22623280.review:
Just finished this game, took me roughly 2.5 hours. What a wild ride! Stray Cat Crossing not only has amazing art and music, but also a story telling style that will get your heart racing and it will be on your mind even after you have finished the game.

[h1]Overview[/h1]
At the first glance at this game, the store page screenshots show that the art style is very unique and eccentric. Having played the game I absolutely agree that the art style played a huge part in creating the atmosphere and immersion of the game. It's made with RPGMaker, however the loving care put into the art, as well as its detail and quality, make it hard to notice the engine at all.

[h1]Thoughts, Story wise[/h1]
The story is about a girl named Cat, that got lost. I really don't want to spoil anything by giving out details, as the story is a crucial part of this story, and emotionally impactful. I'll say that it's a story about memories and the past, kind of like To the Moon's themes. The way the story is implemented is quite outstanding, with different layers to getting to  "what actually happened". In the end the story is revealed bit by bit, with symbolism and twists of reality. It indeed is very thought provoking and I'm still thinking about the events that happened and what the story is trying to say. I absolutely love games/ shows/ anime that do this! What came to mind after playing was Spirited Away by Studio Ghibli, and after this thought occurred to me I looked up the developer's site and it's listed as one of the influences. So kudos to them for conveying the atmosphere right!

[h1]Thoughts, Gameplay wise[/h1]
The game play is generally very smooth, involving puzzles and some chase scenes. I had a lot of fun with the puzzles, and the difficulty is about just right for a game heavily focusing on story - made me use my brain but didn't make me overly frustrated. The first 2 acts are great, the 3rd drags out but felt worth it. However a gripe I had was the speed of talking which is on the slow side and unskippable. The game froze sometimes after saving (thankfully after saving not before!) But looking at an FAQ unfortunately this is due to some problem with the RPGMaker engine, and will not be game breaking on most machines.

[b]Random tips[/b]
1. The chase scene seems hard at first but don't give up! It's actually quite short. You can only jump over the small holes.
2. The OST is free, included in the game files!

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Stray Cat Crossing is a game with great storytelling, with a dark and creepy atmosphere. If you're looking for a thought provoking and emotionally impactful game, look no further! In addition the unique art style and soundtrack will draw you right in. I highly recommend this game - it's a steal at its asking price on Steam.

22407277.review:
Stray Cat Crossing sits at a strange intersection of drama, adventure, and horror. The horror comes from being locked in small areas (typically a single floor of a house) with surrealist characters as your only companions, as well as FMV scenes that interrupt your actions with jumpscares. The characters you encounter are creepy and may antagonize you, but there are very few of them that impede your progress or can send you to the game over screen.

The narrative of Stray Cat Crossing starts out shallow at first. During the first two acts, it seems like the characters are strange for the sake of being strange and no explanations are given for their behaviour. Near the end of the second act is when things start to become deeper, but still very obscured. During the third act, essentially the last half of the game, the loose threads begin to join and form a unified whole. There is a sense of discovery when you find out the significance of a seemingly throwaway task in the earlier part of the game. I was pleased with the way the story came together at the end. It could have been easy to leave everything vague or unanswered in a game as surreal as Stray Cat Crossing, but the developers thankfully brought everything to a conclusion.

Pros:
-the pixel art is wildly original
-the soundtrack swaps between creepy ambience, pastoral guitar plucking, and dissonance as needed
-the full soundtrack is included in the base game!
-story comes to a satisfying conclusion with everything tied up nicely in a big bundle of feels
-different characters have distinct personalities and speech patterns
-about half the puzzles have nothing explaining how to complete them, yet are still intuitive
-the repetition and changing of rooms. Revisiting the same rooms multiple times and seeing how they change as I advanced made an entire level of just three rooms interesting
-I really liked the saving system. Very stylishly done.
-The brevity of the game makes it very easy to finish, and after discovering the secrets at the end, it is worthwhile to play through again to see the foreshadowing.
-Very unique experience. It is not easy to compare with other games

Cons:
-the song "Skin Tight" from the trailer is only as long as it is in the trailer. 0:51 is just not long enough. 
-the controls are not quite ideal. Being an RPG Maker game, I had to search non-Stray Cat Crossing forums to find a way to rebind keys to my comfort and play the game fullscreen without stretching.
-the other half of the puzzles are simply trial and error with little logic beind them
-the hedgemaze: this was a really cool, creepy locale with a completely indecipherable puzzle. After wandering aimlessly for 30 minutes, I simply looked online for the answer to progress. I haven't seen any Let's Play videos figure it out themselves either yet, so am sure it was not just my own problem.
-The repetition of scripted events. This was an annoyance in the third chapter. Rather than merely revisiting rooms, you are forced to sit through scripted events as you replay the same scenes over again, learning a little bit more each time. This would have been awesome if some of the connecting events were cut on subsequent visits. Having an usher always come, say the exact same lines as the three times before, and then walk away, come back, and talk some more is irritating when you simply want to walk into the room you are trying to go to.
-Some of the dialogue can fall a little flat. One of the things that grated on me was a certain character that begins every sentance with "..." waits for awhile, then finally says something.
-The FMV jumpscares that interrupt you early in the game do not tie into the plot anymore than to remind you that things are oh-so-spooky here, but largely die off in the second and third chapters

22346620.review:
Stray Cat Crossing is an interesting game that is more about the story than any serious game play. 

You enter a world that you leaves you guessing and your job is to try to figure out what's going on. The entire game is not your stock RPGMaker game. Custom Art goes a long way, as well as some FMV scenes. The characters you meet are interesting and very different from those you typically would expect to find. You can tell the creators put a lot of love into the creation of this game. 

The puzzles are not too complex or hard to figure out and make sense.

My only complaints are the following:
[list]
[*] The lack of full controller support.
[*] The text speed is fixed and has built in pauses which drove me crazy. I read really fast and felt like I was waiting for the game often when I was done reading.
[*] Act III is more of a chore than it is fun and drags out the last part of the game easily to at least 1.5 times what you've already done in the first 2 acts.
[/list]

Overall the game is a great little adventure for a Sunday morning/afternoon and the price isn't bad for what the game is.

This game deserves a 8/10 for what it is, based on story, price, and entertainment factor.

A fascinating horror story that appears twisted in the beginning. There's a reason for the way it is presented, and it may or may not become apparent to the player as the story goes on. The concept of the story is pretty good. Although I already knew most of what was going to happen, the ending still shocked me and made me pretty emotional.

Strong points
- Story, graphics and music. The last two appears to be well thought out and designed to fit each other and the story itself. Among the three, the music garners my interest the most.

Weak point
- The Theater. From what I experienced, it has to be done in a rather specific sequence. Otherwise, if you messed one part up and saved over your only save file, you have to restart the game all over again since you can't gain that one item back.

Recommendation to potential players
- Keep one save file at the start of the Theater before interacting with anyone so that you don't have to restart the entire game if you mess up by accident.

22130364.review:
Stray Cat Crossing is a short, but intense tour into the rabbithole.
The story's start is pretty simple - you find the young girl called Cat wandering on the streets, and you offer her to take her back to his house - even giving your scarf to her not to catch a cold on your way. But you realize only after her entering the house that she still has your scarf, which is really dear to your heart, so you enter Cat's house to find her and ask her for your scarf.
While the short introduction also plays an important part in understanding the whole story, the real content of the game starts after entering the house.  On your left you see a blind girl, eyes covered with bandages, holding a camera, meekly asking you if she could take a photo of you...  and then you can pick your save slot :)  The game developers really cleverly implemented, and inserted the savepoint system in the game that it's actually a person, who appears at numerous spots during the game, always reflecting to your current actions - it's wonderfully immersive

After speaking to her, you see footprints on the ground, which lead deeper into the house. 
The game consists of three different parts of the house, three chapters - each really different from the other ones, they build on the previous ones but there's a common thing in them - they are all has their own creepy characters, themes and actions that can send shivers down one's spine.  Each chapter gives you a clear goal, and you can reach it by completing smaller goals, sometimes puzzles.  The characters of the house had a similar feeling to me like in Silent Hill - they do have a strong resemblance to asian, or rather japanese horror-creatures, but what sets the macabre tone the best is that they are all clever, thinking - and has no real intention of hurting you. But, if it's possible, they won't let you go. 
The game only has one point when you can die while you're just walking around, but it's more like an event, like a QTE is for a game - and it has a save point just before it, so it's safe to say that while saving is advised, it's not easy to get yourself killed. Which is nice, because you'll be able to spend more time exploring the house, and to see VCR-like short video-cuts appear, that unravels a little more about the story, while conveniently raising the creepy-factor a LOT.
 I don't want to spoi the story, especially as the game is short, can be completed in three hours and it's really worth to be experienced rather than just told about. But as it can be guessed from the lack of combat, the game's story revolves around pretty serious matters, and it's elements presented through the game's symbols, with the whole story explained at the end. While the third, last chapter got pretty tedious compared to the first two, the game really did a great job by not making the story overly simplistic, and at the same the explanation was presented in a way that does not make the player feel stupid for not getting it during the game.

While the art style seemed a little at first (the characters are pretty big compared to the environment) the game did a perfect job at introducing, then gradually unfold and solve a story while making me feel intrested, weirded out, or at some points just staring onto the screen.  I've got the game from a bundle that cost maybe 1.5$ ; but I think if someone's looking for a more creepy-weird, than a scary horror and finds the art direction attractive, I can absolutely recommend the game even at full price.  It's done with RPGMaker but uses own art, has a great soundtrack and has a really nice story with a proper ending that's quite memorable.  It was a great experience for me.

Plus macabre que poétique, Stray Cat Crossing souffre de mécaniques de jeu éculées, fondées sur d'incessants aller et retour, et d'un scénario cousu de fil blanc, mais propose en contrepartie de très beaux graphismes "pixel art" ainsi qu'une ambiance dense, unique en son genre.

On est vite mal à l'aise dans cet écrin glauque, poisseux, peuplé de personnages tous plus dérangeants les uns que les autres, comme prisonniers d'une version Burtonienne d'un long métrage de Miyazaki, ou un Silent Hill mis en scène par Mamoru Hosoda. Certaines scènes, certaines fulgurances vont jusqu'à donner la nausée dès lors qu'on joue le jeu.

Pourtant, lorsqu'on referme la porte derrière soi, lorsqu'on résout la toute dernière énigme, on se rend compte qu'en dépit de l'horreur, du grotesque, du malsain, on s'est attaché à ces drôles de personnages. Qu'on les quitte à regrets, sur les notes d'un très bel ending qui conclue l'expérience par un apaisement salutaire.

Une très jolie curiosité vidéoludique, mais qui pourra égratigner les âmes les plus sensibles.

21512980.review:
The game wasn't actually *terrible*, but I'd have a hard time recommending it to a friend without a bunch of qualifiers.

Like most people have said, the art and music are pretty good. The art isn't quite my style, but it's obviously high quality. The music fits the atmosphere. That atmosphere is well-developed, too. The settings and characters add to the air of mystery throughout most of the game. One point of criticism here: the trailer is pretty misleading. Few of the animations in the trailer are actually used in-game in any way. While the game does have good art, the trailer makes it seem far more well-produced than it actually is.

Unfortunately, the gameplay and story are greatly lacking. If one of the two were lacking, it might be forgiven, but that's not the case. The gameplay is entirely puzzles, which would be fine if the puzzles were at all engaging. At best, the puzzles are insultingly linear and obvious. At worst, the puzzles are not only linear, but also employ moon logic to make you question if it's actually the solution to the puzzles. The areas are small and confined, and you can solve every puzzle in the game by running around and interacting with everything you see until the solution is effectively told to you. There is a chase sequence at one point, and it was well-executed, but it's the only segment of it's kind in the game. I see people complain about the last segment of the game in the attic. I can see how it might be frustrating if it were a difficult puzzle, but I figured out what I needed to do after the first reset. It was pretty quick after that. Also, the description on Steam is a bit misleading. "Challenging riddles and puzzles"? Not quite. "Test your wit to survive"? Failing to answer any of the "riddles" in the game doesn't affect you at all. You just get to try again. There are no consequences.

As for the story, there were definitely some good ideas here, they were just poorly executed and explained. I can appreciate leaving things up to the viewer/player, but this level of vagueness makes it seem less like it was intentional and more like the writer just wasn't sure what he was writing about. I figured out the "plot twist" less than halfway through the game, but admittedly, I was still strung along by the "mystery". That's in quotes because, apparently my idea of what the game's mystery was didn't match up with what the writer was thinking. About halfway through the game, I had pieced together most of the main character's backstory, and who many of the other characters actually were. But, I still had questions: what was going on in this place? Why were things so strange? For the few characters I didn't understand, where did they fit into this? Unfortunately, very few of those questions were answered were answered at all, and none of those answers left me with any sense of satisfaction. Right when I thought the game was just beginning, it ended and left me hanging.

Spoilers ahead:

Cat's backstory is fine and all, but where do characters like the grub/bug woman fit in? Why are there four wolves when we know the blind child has only one dog? Why are they being cursed by the "sphinx" from the story Cat's mother told her? Who is the toy maker? Why is there a ghost thing in the maze that teleports me to the start for some reason? This is just the tip of the iceberg. I suppose I may have just not have been paying attention, but if the house in the game is a memory, what are these things Cat is remembering? Is it all a hallucenation? Magic? Beyond that, how did Cat forget all this stuff in the first place? Does she have amnesia? And what's with that ending? Is it supposed to be another plot twist? A cliff-hanger? Like I said before, vague is one thing, and I love to interpret stories like this, but there's just nothing to go on here. There's nothing to analyze. It's just a bunch of stuff lumped together in a story for seemingly little reason. Even a little more flavor text on items in the world might have helped. More  things to explore on my own, instead of Cat telling me exactly what I'm looking at ("It's a light.", "It's a mirror.", "It's a plant.").

So, ultimately, I can't recommend this for most people. The art is good, the music is good, and if you're really interested in that, the game might be worth $3 just for the short and mildly interesting ride. Most people won't enjoy it, though, I don't think. If the game had cost me much more, I might be mad.

This game is worth every penny. Very refreshing, looks beautiful and genuinely unsettling. I especially loved the palette of colors used - it gives the game a very warm and welcoming feeling, kind of like a cosy rug in front of the fireplace, which makes it all the more jaunting when things get creepy. If you enjoy the kind of aesthetic evoked by the charming and bizarre world of Lewis Carroll, this is a fantastically modern take on a girl's journey down the rabbit hole, with it's own unique cast of colorful, uncanny characters and stream of riddles. 

It should be noted that the game relies heavily on story and player interpretation. You'll be left with more questions than answers at the end and its biggest selling point is definitely its mystery. It is seamlessly atmospheric in that it is both magical and terrifying. The game-play can be quite basic and not always consistent, as you move from adrenaline inducing chase scenes to relaxed puzzle-solving, but Stray Cat Crossing is unwavering when it comes to the narrative, as with many RPG Maker games, and that should be the reason why you choose to play.

20653460.review:
3/5 stars  

I sometimes wish there was a neutral option for Steam Reviews, because while I certiantly didn't dislike my time with Stray Cat Crossing, it's ending third, specifically the part in the theatre, leaves an awful taste in your mouth. 

Anyway, Stray Cat Crossing is a surreal horror RPG maker game, like Ib, Ao Oni, and many other before it. Stray Cat Crossing has a lot more polish than most of those. the pixel art graphics themselves are almost worth the admission price, and the music is also great. The story is definatley above average for a RPG maker romp, telling a sad tale of jealousy and domestic neglect. 

Unfortunatley, not as much love and care was put into the gameplay. Stray Cat Crossing relies on several "tricks" to add artificial length to what otherwise would have been a single sitting game. The most infamous is the theatre section, which I talked about at the start, but it runs through the whole game. Actions (such as rotating a bridge) take ten times as long as they should. An early chase sequence requires you to sit through the same 30 second cutscene every time you retry (And you will die A LOT at that part). A part involving carrying objects slows you down to an absolute slow as hell crawl. All of this builds up, and what started as minor annoyance eventually blossoms into resentment. It feels like the game is wasting your time, and thats never a good feeling. 

Overall, Stay Cat Crossing left me feeling kind of mad, but I can't say I disliked it's macabre world. 

Wait for a sale, if possible.

20310508.review:
So I was pretty excited to pick this game up after having played the demo what seems like ages ago.  So now having beaten the game let's get to the pros and cons of Stray Cat Crossing.

Cons:

- This one might be more of a Windows 10 issue, but this game crashes a lot.  If you press two buttons on the joypad at once, if you accidentally press a non-bound button on your joypad, if you attempt to combine items and so on.  Basically if you give it an excuse to crash it most certainly will.  Fortunately the frequency of save-points is an effective stopgap.

- The lack of volume control.  The volume levels of the music tracks are all over the place and you have no in-game way to adjust the volume.  Some tracks are still deafening at minimum volume settings on my headphones and others need to be turned up to be heard.

- The game is short, like really short.  You can pretty much subtract a half hour of play-time from having to re-do things before I got OCD about saving.  It feels like you've got three quarters of a game here with the semi-final act missing.  Now while I'm sure the creators of the game intended to leave things vague to add to the surrealness of the experience; I feel like it left a lot of characters under-developed.

But with that said there are some real positives to the game:

+ The music is good stuff, volume levels aside.  It's got the creepy minimalist vibe to it; which enhances the experience.

+ There is some great surreal imagery here.  I played this ony my Twitch stream and there were a lot of instances where what I saw caused me to just stop talking mid-sentence to wrap my head around things.  I want to keep my review spoiler free, so it's hard to go into detail, but nothing is quite as it seems in this game.

+ The art itself in the game is great.  I think the game strives to have it's own sense of style while still delivering a 16 bit retro feel to it.

So the bottom line is that you are basically getting 3/4ths of a good game; but when you factor in the price of the game you're really getting some decent bang for your buck.

19537607.review:
This is one of the better RPG Maker games I've played.

Pros:
-Good, consistent visual style.
-Great soundtrack and atmosphere.
-Interesting story that engrosses the player.
-Interesting puzzle mechanics and difficulty progression.

Cons:
-Early on there's a lot of video cuts that are supposed to be scary. They're kind of jarring and don't really fit with the game and aren't particularly scary.
-The plot doesn't progress organically. It makes an abrupt jump from creepy 2spooky4u to generic "solve the mystery" style adventure game. When the game's plot goes from vague to specific it becomes overly specific and kind of removes the mystery while still trying to present the story in a vague way. It gets tedious fast.
-The end of the game becomes very tedious and boring as on your first try you will end up replaying the same segment over and over as it's trial and error based.

Overall it's not bad for an RPG Maker game. The creators did a really good job of creating an atmosphere using a medium that doesn't really allow for much variety in gameplay or presentation. It's worth trying out the demo at the very least but keep in mind that it's a <2hr RPG Maker game before you buy it.

19120951.review: A game with incredible visuals paired with a beautiful soundtrack. As with many other RPG pixel games, you must get through the game by fulfilling a series of puzzles. As you progress through the game, the puzzles get slightly harder. One thing that could have been done differently is the last puzzle. I'll admit, I probably would not have been able to finish the game without glancing over a walkthrough :X There isn't too much horror in this game, but there are a few jumpscares and situations that leaves you with an eerie, creepy sensation. As for the game itself, there is a lot of symbolism and the ending gives the player the freedom of open interpretation. I would definitely recommend this to anyone who enjoys a wonderfully put together RPG pixel game.

19076977.review:
My main problem with this game is it wraps up too nicely. The ending kind of runs into itself without giving it a chance to do something else, or let it ease into things. The other fact of it only taking me 2 hours to beat the entire thing (including getting every bit of dialogue in the play) kind of supports that need that the game finishes up a little too fast for its own good. It would have been nice to spend some more time in places that might have needed it. Ending doesn't really give me that feeling of "it's over" or that it was about to be over or that everything is all set in the end (connections of characters etc. remains foggy but maybe intentionally).

This being said I was gotten a lot. It was great gets of me, a funny way of saying it, and this game really worked well with some tropes and not so much tropes (I'm referring to the way the play works which I think is a little flawed but altogether an interesting way of using time travel - I don't know how many roses I ended up with but I kept collecting them) of RPG games, kind of alluding to something like Misao or y'know, a lot of 'those types' of games. Would like to see more from the people who made it - obviously the sprites are great and probably its most appealing feature. There's more to it that works pace-wise for the first half so well (my thoughts are that later it's a little less done well, but still ok) that really make everything come together.

18667864.review:
It's a good idea, and there was the potential for something memorable here. It's ruined by tedious design and its own obsession with weirdness above all else. Normally I wouldn't review a game I hadn't finished, but in this case I really couldn't be bothered to keep going and had seen the same problems repeated enough times that there was no reason to believe they'd suddenly go away in the second half. 

The good: 
- Character and world art
- A few ambient tracks

The bad:
- Level design forces repeatedly crossing the same screens for no reason at all, some times accompanied by pointlessly slow and unskippable dialogue and animations. 
- Puzzles are either insultingly obvious or tedious. 
- All but one of the tracks that doesn't fall under the above are mildly annoying. The last one starts out alright, but becomes an absolute cacophony halfway through and never recovers. 
- Unintentionally hilarious rather than scary. Horror generally gets to me pretty easily. SCC is one of the first times I've never come close to being scared - after an initial surprise, the game's attempts at nightmarish visions and monstrous transformations were just funny. 
- Where there's quests, there's fetch quests. 

For the price, it's probably worthwhile just to experience the madness for an hour or two. I can't call it good, but it's undeniably entertaining in the right mood.

18658345.review:
(Review originally published [url=http://gamemoir.com/indie-video-games/stray-cat-crossing-gorgeous-face-on-an-uneven-game/]on Gamemoir[/url].)

Recently, I have been mulling over horror games made in RPG Maker. So when it was brought to me attention that there was an intriguing new title known as Stray Cat Crossing, I had to give it a look over. And while it is far from a complete horror experience, it is an exceptional case of RPG Maker horror done right. A signpost of sorts to guide the way.
 
Indie devs Jurlo and JetPackGone have created a wonderful, beautiful, creepy little game in Stray Cat Crossing. It goes in the right direction, but never quite reaches its destination.

After the first few minutes of Stray Cat Crossing, I was hooked. It grabs the player with some astoundingly pretty presentation. The graphics are reminiscent of GameBoy Advance-era 2D pixel art—charming if sparing animated brightly colored sprites set upon creative backdrops. The world of Stray Cat Crossing is bizarre and fascinating, a fantastical mixture of Silent Hill and Alice in Wonderland. It features creepy anthropomorphic creatures, Japanese Noh masks, freaky babies and theatrical interludes. The horror isn’t outright—the emphasis is placed more upon weirdness and subtle uncanniness. Jurlo’s music manages to bring calm and fright to the atmosphere, laying as it does somewhere between Akira Yamaoka and Yasunori Mitsuda.

Stray Cat Crossing places nearly all of its strength into its presentation and atmosphere, and boy does it ever perform this well. Beautiful graphics and sound-work, effective art direction and a flurry of inspirations that come together as something wholly unique. These facets make it worth the price of admission.

Unfortunately, this does not make the whole game. Not everyone places so much value on the presentation. The regrettable flipside of Stray Cat Crossing comes from its two greatest weaknesses: Un-engaging gameplay and a lazily vague plot.

The gameplay, by itself, is serviceable. Definitely a flaw, but not altogether bad. It simply suffers from never feeling cohesive. One doesn’t get the sense that there was much design philosophy behind the gameplay. There are occasional inventory puzzles. There is one chase sequence involving light platforming. There are some dialogue puzzles. Yet none of this ever seems to come together—they feel like challenge added for the sake of having a sense of gameplay, rather than the game organically developing its play.

I’m reminded of the Charnel House Trilogy, which the developer Ashton Raze has admitted did not lend itself well to gameplay. But the devs at Owl Cave Games managed to accept that and work around the game’s inherent shortcomings, doing what they could to make it engaging as a game despite not having much by way of challenge. Stray Cat Crossing‘s gameplay feels like a sequence of arbitrary puzzles—some challenging, others not so much—that in the grand scheme just don’t match the rest of the game. They may be filtered over with the game’s atmosphere (filling a fountain in a dark garden with the right amount of water in order to save a giant bug, only to inadvertently lead that bug to be eaten), but they don’t feel like they fit. Puzzles in Stray Cat Crossing are always obstacles. They simply never feel like progress.

In addition to this, some of the puzzles are just plain bad. The horrendously repetitive final act involves exchanging various items with people in order to gain the script to a play, allowing the play to finish and the game the move forward. Only one must perform the previous scenes of the play multiple times in order to speak to the correct people and obtain the right items. It is essentially one large, monotonous fetch quest, quite unwelcome at any point in a game but especially right at the end.

Then we come to the story. Now, Stray Cat Crossing‘s story is by no means bad. In fact there is a lot to like about it. It touches on themes of childhood, jealousy, loss and regret. But its way of being told really distances the player from these themes, leaving them with neither a solid narrative nor a sympathetic character to connect to. Rather we get a quirky cast of one-dimensional creatures and a few curious but ultimately nondescript humans.

The vague story in indie games has been bugging me for a while now. Perhaps popularized by Limbo, one of the few to actually perform it right, a great deal of indie games have been turning to player interpretation narratives. In only a few isolated cases is the vagueness ever a complement to the overall game. Limbo, for instance, works because it never makes any attempt to really tell a complex story—it only asks that the player experience this weird German expressionist-inspired journey. Another example, Lone Survivor, meanwhile gets a pass because it is a conscious experimentation in dream logic. Stray Cat Crossing doesn’t have these excuses. The execution of the story, as a result, comes off as lazily constructed—a nonlinear sequence of events assembled as a means to set the aforementioned great atmosphere together. They could have combined much more smoothly, but this lack of synchronicity between them causes the story to simply drag the atmosphere down.

Thus we have the three pillars of Stray Cat Crossing—atmosphere, gameplay, narrative—and only one is stable. These pillars rely on each other to hold the game up, but Stray Cat Crossing put all its weight on one. And while it doesn’t quite cause the whole game to collapse, the strain definitely pushes the overall experience down a bit.

I like a lot about Stray Cat Crossing, don’t get me wrong. It just doesn’t hold up as a game on its own. If Jurlo and JetPackGone were to team up again for something more cohesively designed, that would be absolutely worth checking out.

18473629.review:
I would compare this game, both visually and audibly, to that of a Miyazaki movie. 

There's something about the dark allure, twisted characters, and poetical sense of realisation that will completely entrance you as you play. I'll keep this review short and sweet, as not to give too much away, for I believe its the  mystery that truly immerses you into this world. If you're a fan of the darker works of Tim Burton, Hideo Kojima, Neil Gaiman or Studio Ghibli, then I hope you'll take my word in faith and purchase this game without reading too much about it. 

It was a game I played from start to finish- that rare feeling of wanting to play it all at once, though you know you shouldn't or it will all be over too soon (and I'll admit I got no sleep last night because of it). The graphics are beautiful, the art pulls inspiration from all corners of the world, the music is perfect and it has a glistening array of eccentric characters. 

That's not to say it's not without fault. Admittedly I struggled for great lengths of time on some of the puzzles, and even had to look to walkthroughts. At one point it got very repetitive, but honestly I can only say that added to my immersion, a true sense of desperation as you get trapped in this house of horrors. 

On the surface it's polished, well written and exciting, though it truly is a three dimensional game (metaphorically, pardon the pun) its exploration of the darker side of the human psyche left me wanting to play it again from a new perspective.

I can only say- for £1.99 this game is a complete steal. I'm awestruck.

18436308.review:
There's a surprising number of RPG Maker horror games, if you've never looked. Most ditch the RPG trappings entirely in favor of a minimalist retro-2D walking simulator style, and most of those tend to be boring or poorly designed. But every once in awhile you'll find a gem in the pile, and Stray Cat Crossing is one of those gems.

Your lovingly-rendered character happens across a small girl wandering the road at night. The girl, Cat, runs off with your treasured scarf and you follow her all the way home like the worst sort of creeper just to get it back. Don't feel bad, though, because her house is full of all kinds of nightmare beings. SCC is a surreal adventure game through symbolic realms of guilt and loss, expressed in a magnificently detailed and colorful art style. Characters are memorable, environments are vivid, and the atmosphere is excellent.

The sound design is on point as well, but the real stand-outs are the bizarre video clips the game hits you with periodically. Every once in awhile, you'll be interrupted by a short scene that looks cut from the VHS tape in The Ring. These sequences are incredibly jarring and effective. I am not a fan of jumpscares in the least, but these felt well thought-out and earned. They add immeasurably to the atmosphere and help hint at future story beats, as well.

The story itself is quite good, managing to dabble heavily in symbolism and moralizing without falling into the traps other games often do. There's nothing forced or heavy-handed about the plot developments, and you tend to catch up with things as your tight-lipped protagonist does. The one place the game stumbles is in the puzzles, which start off strong and clever but end on some sour notes. The final sequence is honestly quite clever as well, but in a way that's not actually very fun to get through. It comes at the very end, though, so at that point there's no reason not to power through for the satisfying finale.

You'll finish the game in two hours or so, which is perfectly fine considering the price. They're a tense and emotional two hours that would be worth experiencing just for the cast and atmosphere. Luckily, the whole game pulls together to form something I can whole-heartedly recommend.

18373446.review:
My first contact with Stray Cat Crossing was through the trailer posted on some video game news website and the artistic aspects of it got me hooked pretty fast. 

It's the story of this young woman that one day meets a little girl named Cat and because of reasons, our protagonist ends up going on this weird paranormal adventure through Cat's house. The game follows up a really strict pattern, each place in the house has it story, characters and puzzles and you go trough them as the story guides you.

The gameplay isn't really the focus here, and when the developers try make it the focus they fail. As you can see in the game description, Stray Cat Crossing was made using the RPGMaker and the game have a little list of flaws because of it as little freezes, crashes and others who are more bad design choices like the infamous escape from the basement or the loop sequence at the attic. 

The game REALLY shines through the story and the things related such as the visuals and music. Going against the preconception of games made through the RPGMaker, this one uses really good looking assets and the art style is really unique, it is creepy but in a way that fires up your curiosity and the same can be said of the music. The plot that starts quite simple at its premise evolves quickly on the 2 hour long game into a sweet story about what is a family and how much love can change bad feelings such as guilt and regret.

Although not perfect, this game is great and I'd recommend it to anyone who likes this kind of short experiences. Oh, and I believe that saying that this is a horror game is a little bit too much...? It isn't scary at all and you shouldn't buy it expecting to shit your pants and stuff.

18366870.review:
After meeting a lost girl named Cat you give her your scarf and make sure she reaches home safely: once you get there you realize you forgot to ask to have your scarf back though. You try and get inside to quickly look for her and get your belongings but the house is empty, weird footprints go towards a door and you start to experience strange visions.
Stray Cat Crossing is an RPG maker horror game featuring lots of surreal imagery, dialogues and characters, a cryptic story and some puzzles in between.

[b]PROS:[/b]

-the pixel graphics look simple, but are quite detailed and manage to render the various areas and characters quite well

-great sound design, the various noises are appropriately creepy

-very good soundtrack

-great atmosphere, the various levels you move through and creatures you meet look as something straight out of a bad nightmare

-the story is never fully revealed, but what's there is pretty interesting and touching

-powerful ending

[b]NEUTRAL:[/b]

-the whole plot might be a bit too murky and cryptic for its own good, while some'll appreciate the amount of conjecture this brings others might be disappointed at only having hints regarding what truly happened

[b]CONS:[/b]

-puzzles are either easily solved or can feel a bit awkward, requiring some trial and error until you realize what you need to do, they're never truly challenging or satisfying to be honest

-a chase scene during ACT I is truly frustrating, requiring you to quickly run side-to-side while jumping over holes with little room for error: too bad the controls simply aren't good enough for what's required and this quickly becomes a tiring and frustrating section

-Act III requires repetition to solve the final puzzle and get everything you need, think of it as something out of Groundhog Day: while the premise is interesting there's too much repetition involved, and the same lines over and over, to mantain a decent momentum. If you make a mistake in the sequence then things will be even worse as you're forced to retry over and over

-a couple of exit points from areas can easily be overlooked, leaving you stuck until you find them 

-pretty short,I was done in about 2 hours

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=531146187

Stray Cat Crossing is a somewhat difficult game to review to be honest, I feel it sports a great atmosphere and a quite engaging story backed by gameplay that's somewhat dull or uninteresting in comparison: while Act I was genuinely creepy and enjoyable Act II and III felt like a step backwards in terms of gameplay with puzzles that ended up more annoying than anything else.

If you can endure the somewhat lacking gameplay the story is truly good though, there's lots of surreal imagery, half-hidden truths, metaphors and disconcerting implications that easily pull the game into the realm of psychological horror: what truly happened is left unclear though and you can find lots of theories in the Discussion area.

The aforementioned story, ambience and imagery are why I'm giving it a thumbs up since they made the game a decent experience overall: do consider the various pros and cons mentioned above before deciding if this game can be good for you though.

Nice and short but well-done. I am not so great at puzzles, but this game was doable even with my lack in skills regarding all things puzzle-related. It is very tasteful, and, simply put, very pleasing. There is enough mystery to keep you going throughout and enough hints to help you piece everything together slowly but surely. It is not thoroughly scary, more likely morose and melancholic with elements of surreality. The music was enjoyable as well. It wasn't obnoxious, and it set the mood. 

The only con I could possibly think of was that it was short, but it was really worth it considering the price and the quality of the game overall. It is possible to finish the game in one or two sittings (the general consensus seems to agree that it takes about 2-3 hours to finish). I'm not sure what I think about the replay value yet. Maybe after some time has passed I will go through another playthrough to see if I missed any little things, but the game is satisfying enough after one playthrough.

There is one thing I've got to mention though, as this definately ist not a horror game! Sure, the atmosphere is quite gloomy but I honestly could not have felt any true horror. Great psychological horror game from independent studio and one of the best RPG Maker games out there. It doesn't look much at first but the mood slowly grows on you as you progress further. You'll most likely end the game with many underlying questions but mind me, all answers are already there.

I recommend this to anyone who likes those types of games. It's great 2-3 hours of intriguing story and very memorable experience.

18022853.review:
Just finished this game after about 3 hours so here's my review. 

What initially drew me in to this title was the whole presentation of it and the name: Stray Cat Crossing sounds eerie, cats have been often associated with witchcraft or some sort of evil messegers or messagers of the dead, so I half expected what this game was going to be about. Of course, I was surprised who the actual "cat" was and how the real cat had such a trivial role. By saying that, I don't mean it in a bad way. 
The soundtrack is definitely the best part of the game, it's very atmospheric and I would really be able to listen to it when I'm in need of some good instrumentals. I also very much loved the mini-animated clips when the screen would randomly turn to static; the first time it creeped the hell out of me lol; but they're very artistic. 
This is a rpg mostly focused on gathering "pieces" that make off the overall story and so, most part of the game is going to be focused on puzzles. I personally am a very big fan of these types of rpgs and this one was not a disappointment in that particular area. I had fun trying to solve the puzzles and I didn't find them particularly brain wrecking, so don't worry. Just take a bit of time and you'll manage to solve them on your own.
I have to also praise the writing when it comes to the dialogues/monologues between the twins. They were, to say the least, fantastic! It really reminded me of TweedleDee and TweedleDum of Alice in Wonderland. Maybe there was a refference there, though I don't know. XD I would be able to relate this game with Alice in Wonderland for some elements, mostly because on some parts it's quite "unique" and "twisted". But don't expect a girl in a blue dress and a white rabbit. That you won't get. It's more of a "feeling". 
The thing that I'm disappointed in though, is the ending and the revelation of what truly happened. I can't exactly say why; maybe on one side I found it a bit "trivial" and "too simple". There wasn't any big revelation in the ending, just didn't have enough impact to care about it properly. And it was kind of annoying to repeat the same scene at the end for like 5 times without able to at least skip on the already read text. 
But overall I still recommend it. 3$ is not much, and it deserves them. 

Other games like this one that I would like to recommend if anybody's interested are: Ib, Mad Father, Witch's House and the Crooked Man.
