17922551.review:
Not your typical horror RPG game, Stray Cat Crossing is more of a Through the Looking Glass style tale about a girl named Cat and the disturbing world that surrounds the house that she has gone into while making off (unknowingly) with your scarf. Why you need this scarf so much and just why this house seems to hold so many nightmares within is soon explained in three parts.

Admittedly, I was waiting for Stray Cat Crossing since greenlight and now that it's out (and cheap) I was happy to play it. You'll be able to play this in one sitting. At the most, you'll do three hours if you're getting stuck. You probably won't.

There's no real combat in this game other than fleeing from a few monsters. Most of the time you'll be scratching your head over some moderate brain benders, but nothing is really too tricky in this game. The hardest puzzle is the red larvae passwords and that shouldn't be too hard if you listen to the other hints from the larva and try to draw connections to the storyline in that area. You'll figure it out eventually, I promise.

This game is unusually storyline-rich. There's less gore and less emphasis on the jumpscares (they are there, however, but tend to pop up only in relevance to what you're doing) and more on figuring out Cat's story. I find that some RPG horror games can overdo it on the scaring you out of your skin aspect. This game seeks to disturb you and keeps you involved by introducing these figures in Cat's life. You're immediately shown that Cat feels guilty over something, but why? What is wrong with this tiny little girl and why are you chasing her through this nightmare house that Tim Burton might rent for a summer vacation?

The music is rather beautiful in the game. I was disappointed to not hear the trailer music anywhere (I'll live!), but every level was delightful. Leaving the game on pause for a quick break wasn't a nightmare. I can see (and hear) the effort. The jumpscare cutscenes are animated very well and while not something that certainly scared me, but made me feel uncomfortable and with an impending sense of doom. I preferred that over screaming in horror. I loved the design of the characters and how other-worldly they felt. While the main character was the only "normal" person there, supposedly, they also had a special look to them as well, which made me feel like there was something more.

Now that I've lavished praise, let me talk about my dislikes of the game. I was reduced to only using the arrow keys. A mild annoyance and once I was able to sprint, I didn't complain as much. It gave me a reason to rest my hands across the keyboard. However, after only using the jump function for one part of the game, it was relatively useless. I would have loved to see it again after I had mastered it. (Because that is one angry fetus monster and he did eat me a few times!)

Since I'm a handicapped gamer and I often make reference to it, there is quite a bit of flashing graphics in this game. Do not, by any means, play this game if you are prone to seizures. This game may cause severe migraines. Please take a break and do not play straight through. Otherwise, it wasn't too awful. It's not so much a negative as I was neutral on it. Not my favorite, but if I could have turn it off, I would have loved to.

What I loved the most from Stray Cat Crossing is that I didn't expect needing to grab a box of tissues by the end. I was sobbing. I was hugging my laptop and sobbing. I've already mentioned it, but allow me to do so again. The storyline really has a lovely build up. You're already piecing together the truth, but once everything is revealed and you have your confirmation of Cat's life, you will feel like your heart is being ripped out. With emotional lines and capturing the feelings of love between family members and friends, Stray Cat Crossing has a theme of love and never forgetting your past, even if it gives you some of the greatest pain you can ever endure.

Play it. It's a good way to blow off two hours and it really is cheap. You won't get your typical horror rocks off from it, but it's a much more artsy style of horror.

From what I saw of the ending? I hope that means the story really isn't over. Not just yet.

17901731.review:
This game has probably the best atmosphere of any RPG maker game I've ever played. The visuals are so much better than Ib or Witch's House or really any of those games; SCC has a beautiful art style that perfectly fits the dreamlike quality of the game, and the soundtrack is absolutely stunning. It is at times reminiscient of movie scores by Atticus Ross and Trent Reznor (Gone Girl, The Social Network, Girl with the Dragon Tattoo), eerie and discordant, and at times creepy carnival music—an appreciated cliché. 

It's not a particularly scary game after you complete the first "stage," but it does maintain a very unsettling atmosphere the entire time. You even feel, in the best way possible, faintly unsettled after the ending. 

What I really enjoy about SSC is that it doesn't hold your hand through the puzzles. Often when I play RPG maker games it feels like I'm just constantly being spoon-fed instructions, and it takes away from the actual fun of the gameplay. Of course, there is the opposite problem of not being given any direction and subsequently becoming really lost, but SCC's puzzles were never so difficult as to frustrate me and detract from the immersion. Instead, you feel satisfied for solving something on your own in a reasonable amount of time.

The story itself wasn't anything incredible; by around halfway through the game, I felt like I already (mostly) knew what was going on. However, the game's symbolism of that story is awesome. I plan on going back and playing it a second time just so I can fully appreciate the rich imagery, as well as little details hidden in book titles and whatnot.

Although the characters weren't particularly compelling, esp. the main character, I didn't mind at all. SCC felt like playing a work of art; it didn't need a 3D main character to make the game interesting. The visuals, gameplay and symbolism were more than enough to make SCC an enjoyable experience.

TL;DR - Great game. Amazing atmosphere and music. Rich symbolism and imagery. Good, smart gameplay. Worth it!

17840669.review:
I would like to give it a neutral review, as the it has both many pro and many cons, and I can see why people would both like and dislike this game. But ultimately the craftsmanship and care is what makes me give the game a positive review.

On the pro side; The pixel art is superb, easily the best I've seen in an RPGmaker game, it has a lot of detail in everything, and it makes the unique and surreal designs comes to life. The atmospheric soundtrack makes it even better. The story was well done. The first act was great, it had both solid puzzles, suspense/horror elements and introduce the player to the world and its surreal nature pretty effectively.

Now on to the downsides. This game pretty short, clocking in around 2 hours long. Another big issue is that while the first act is great, the second and third act are drug down by some tedious puzzles that are on the unintitutive side and require a bit too much trial and error or repetition to complete and ultimately detract from the experience. The horror and suspense elements are also gone after the first act as well. Lastly, aside from the introduction sequence, the first act was released for free as a pre-release teaser/demo, so the best part of the game is free and was played by many people (such as myself) months before the game was finished.

That being said, the skills of the developers certainly have some well honed talent, I sincerely hope they take the criticisms to heart and make more games with that in mind. I look forward to what they will make next.

17837163.review: Stray Cat Crossing is one of the better indie RPG Maker-style games I've played in a while. The game looks lovely - the visuals are surreal and unique. It's clear the game is drawing heavily from Alice In Wonderland, but it doesn't simply directly reference its source material by having rabbits and whatnot. Instead, it feels more like an original setting, with its Japanese influenced art and cartoonish character designs. The dialogue is also great, giving you just enough information about the setting and story. The gameplay has more variety than what I was expecting - one puzzle in the middle of the game was particularly interesting. I liked that the game tried to make sure that the puzzles were intuitive through gameplay, without much specific info-dump-like dialogue. This breaks down at the end - the final puzzles are tedious and require a lot of fetch quests and rewatching cutscenes over and over and over without the ability to skip through them or speed up dialogue. It really took away from the rest of the game and I almost didn't recommend this game over it. However, the story and the rest of the puzzles are strong enough that the game is worthwhile. I'd recommend picking it up if you want to enjoy a short story through gameplay.

17822681.review:
SCC OST is easily one of my favorite new albums to listen to. The game itself was a semi-memorable experience. Is it horror? Not really. Were there jump scares? A few. Most reviewers have commented on the Alice in Wonderland vibe as well as the more Ghibli-esque elements so I won't mention those here.

One mechanic I found interesting, albeit frustrating, occurs during the first level with Baby face. Once you complete "favors for favors" you are presented with verbose seemingly redundant dialogue. If the player scrolls through too quickly they will auto-select "yes" to a question that ulitmately ends the game. While annoying for some, this mechanic caused me to slow down and take note of the game design's self awareness. 

--Aesthetic, SCC knows who it is and what it's going for. Overall, I felt it was similar to "The Witch's House" with much nicer graphics. 
--Story itself was fairly predictable, no "twists" or "turns" to really speak of. 
--Dialogue was average
--Level design was enjoyable until the third arc which was repititive with little to no payoff.
--Replayability: little to none

TL;DR: I sound hyper critical but the game was an enjoyable experience. For only 2.99 it does, relatively, what it sets out to do which is provide the player with a creepy visual novel of sorts. 17819013.review:
This game left me with a mixed feeling.
On the one hand the artwork accompanied by a very good soundtrack drew me in. On the other hand the gameplay itself, due to being limited by the RPG Maker rules, and also due to being strictly reduced to puzzle solving, did not keep me interested as much as I thought I would be after watching the trailer. 
The puzzles can be very tedious. These are the kind of puzzles I always hated in similar games, since they purposely prolong the gameplay by giving away only tiny hints, while the player must often traverse the scenes multiple times to find the solution. Be prepared to be annoyed after a while, especially during the event in the attic. 

The horror element in this game is also pretty much nonexistent unless you are very easily frightened. Maybe my expectations were beyond what one should expect from a RPG Maker game, I don't know.

Even without taking its overall shortness into account, what I do know howewer is, that despite its semi-interesting story, good artwork and soundtrack I was not entertained, shocked or mystified by this game at all, and I wouldn't recommend it to other people despite it's low price tag.

If you are into puzzle solving, mysterious and/or macabre stories, that Pan's Labyrinth/ twisted Alice in Wonderland feeling, I would strongly recommend getting "Fran Bow", another adventure game recently released on Steam. 
I played that game before this one, maybe that is why it left me utterly unimpressed, depite the interesting premise.

17795582.review:
Stray Cat Crossing is a nice little narrative adventure. There isn't much in the way of challange to it but that's alright. The core of the gameplay can be summed up as bumping from point A to point B, interacting with something or someone in order to advance the story. There are several puzzles thrown in to spice things up a bit, which is certainly a welcome decision. Everything is pretty straightforward, though, so there is little chance to get stuck for more than a couple of minutes at the same point. The single exception to this could be a small but very unforgiving action sequence (which I sincerely hope is tonned down at some point).

The story is intriguing, though the game never really takes the time to explain some details and lets the player imagination fill the gaps. The music is great and adds a lot to the ambience. The art is nice too and has a lot of personality. The backgrounds can get a bit repetitive, but they are populated with big, detailed props which really help to ease that feeling. All these elements feel well integrated with nice shadowing arround them and simple lighting effects livening things up a bit. The sound effects are maybe a bit lacking, with very simple PSG-like samples played to give feedback about things like locked doors.

As for the tone of the game, it certainly fits the horror label in the beginning. But this aspect is progressively downplayed and the final act pretty much drops it completly. If you come expecting a traditional horror experience you may feel disapointed.

All in all, I really enjoyed this title and found it's release price very fitting. My compliments to the developers.

I stumbled on this game by chance. I don't normally check the recent releases on Steam, but I lucked into seeing this on the day of release.

I've enjoyed other RPGmaker games like The Witch's House and Ib and I think this fits right in in that canon. The pixel art is absolutely beautiful and makes a good use of the engine both artistically and puzzle-wise. I loved the art a lot, especially the little animated snippets.

The music was particularly beautiful. I look forward to a soundtrack coming out as DLC.

I got a bit frustrated by the one section that required fast reflex running and jumping. It seemed out of place with the rest of the slow exploration and puzzle solving of the rest of the game. It took me a lot of tries to get past it, and had me cussing out loud! But I got past it in the end and was glad there was no more. 

On the whole I thought it was a very lovely game. The horror element is more atmospheric and creepy than any outright scares. That's the kind of thing I like. I may play this one again just to experience it!

And one, trying to be more objective: the game atmosphere, the graphics, the storyline: not very innovative. 17763734.review:
I came across Stray Cat Crossing (no pun intended) while scanning the greenlight community, and idk why but the title design pulled me in; I proceeded to watch the trailer, to which my inner weeaboo was satisfied (animated trailer and that music, it was like watching a JRock MV), so I gave the demo a try. The Alice in Wonderland vibe I got from the game hooked me for good and I was definitely interested in the final product upon release. This purchase did not leave me disappointed.

You start off as an unamed girl merely being a decent human being to a lost child named Cat by escorting her home, and when you reach your destination you're pulled into a house of mysterious creatures and settings as you discover just who Cat is. Now, I'm not familiar with games made from RPG maker - though I have heard some negative things - but in my opinion this is one of the better ones. The pixel art is indeed gorgeous and well done (the cutscenes served their purpose well too), and the puzzles were a perfect balance of "Oh, I know this," and "Hmm, gotta actually think." It's not really horror in the traditional sense of inducing fear, but I suppose one could see some of the creatures and actions as disturbing. The soundtrack was hauntingly perfect and set the mood for everywhere the protagonist traveled, and as the plot unfolded before my eyes I was surprised in a bittersweet way.

The only gripes I had with this game is the keyboard layout and steam overlay. Although the controls are few and simple (up, down, left, right to move, enter/space to interact, shift to run, and A to jump), there was only the one scene where jump was introduced that I had trouble with. It felt awkward using shift and A at the same time and I wish I could've changed the jump command from A to space, but I managed through the scene. As for the steam overlay it's nonexistent, and while it's not necessarily a bad thing, it would've been nice to know that attempting to screenshot via F12 would actually bring me back to the menu screen and I hadn't saved for a while.

All in all, I could totally see this game extended a bit since I was left with a few questions, but for $2.99 and roughly 2 hours of gameplay I definitely recommend Stray Cat Crossing. It's a short but good one.

17763398.review:
I recommend this game if pretty visuals and beautiful soundtracks are major parts in your gaming experience. 

I played the demo a few days before and was very excited to play the full version. The demo covers tthe first act of three in the game. I was interested by the Ghibli-styled horror, and the first act delivered some chilling moments. However, after the first act I felt the game tone the horror down. Nothing really comes after you and the sense of dread is replaced by wonder, which is alright by I really wanted a horror experience, especially after the first act. The third act is item fetching and LOTS of repetition, and the horror elements are completely sapped.

The story is interesting, but not without poor writing. Lots of unneccessary characters and too many unexplained details. It's not hard to figure out what exactly happened by the end, but there are questions that will nag at you.

This game has incredible visuals for a 2D game. The characters are well designed and the locations are incredible. This and the amazing soundtrack are the best parts about this game.

Gameplay is alright. You have a run button to go places faster and there is one instance where you have the option to jump. Puzzles are way too easy. There's only one or two instances where you might die, so the rest plays like an interactive novel.

40897587.review:
Мне грустно давать этой игре негативную оценку, но создатели настолько увлеклись созданием метафоричной и сюрреалистичной истории, что забыли про игрока. Stray Cat Crossing вращается в своём собственном измерении и остаётся недосягаемой, непонятной даже после финальных титров. 
Основная сюжетная линия - [spoiler]болезненные воспоминания детства, вытесненные в подсознание[/spoiler] - успевает раскрыть себя и сама по себе она хороша. Но помимо неё в игре очень много завязок, загадок, которые остаются недосказанными и оборванными. Они определённо важны, иначе бы их не включали в предфинальный эпизод, где раскрывается вся сюжетная линия, но их смысл остаётся тайной... и это раздражает. Я завершила историю, но множество вопросов повисло в воздухе - не открытыми к интерпретации, но обрубленными, будто часть контента вырезали в последний момент.

Не помогает и то, что геймплейно Stray Cat Crossing выполнена не лучшим образом: в типичный point&click зачем-то вставили аркадный бег от монстров (с очень неудобным назначением клавиш, и их никак не поменять), длинный лабиринт и самое главное - откровенно затянутую часть с театром, где одну и ту же сцену нужно перепроходить минимум 5 раз (у меня получилось даже больше). Эти вставки не работают на атмосферу - они раздражают, портят впечатление от игры и создают впечатление, что проект пытались растянуть до необходимых двух часов.

В Stray Cat Crossing есть хорошие моменты: аккуратная и очень красивая пиксельная графика, несложные задачки, приятная музыка (по большей части), тёмная и сюрреалистичная история о демонах в нашей голове и о том, что все забытые, вытесненные кошмары рано или поздно возвращаются. 
Если бы она была доработана, закончена, я бы с радостью дала ей положительную оценку. Но в сюжетной игре можно закрыть глаза на плохой геймплей, но не сюжетные дыры. Поэтому увы, но я не советую брать Stray Cat Crossing, если только вы совсем не изголодались по инди-проектам с интригующей историей.

40725480.review:
Stray Cat Crossing is a solid addition to indie pixel horror games. It boasts beautifully crafted art and a surreal dark fantasy story about loss and loneliness. The game does a very good job building a creepy yet alluring atmosphere using art, music, and surreal imagery. The puzzles in the game are challenging and interesting without ever being too frustrating or obscure. The game hooked me in from start to finish.

The game length is short, only 2-2.5 hours maximum, so I’d say the price is fair for what the game delivers.

It’s not a perfect game by any means though. Some of the things in the game that I thought were not so great are:

- some of the music tracks sounded grating to me, which is a shame since most of the soundtrack is decent or good
- one of the last few puzzles gets tediously repetitive 
- the protagonist never really seems fazed by any of the crazy things that happen around her??? Which I found odd. Her personality can come off as rather bland.
- Quite a bit of the story is left ambiguous/open to interpretation, which can be both interesting and somewhat annoying.

On a side note, the game also has a few jumpscares if you aren’t a fan of those. 

Regardless, Stray Cat Crossing overall is worthwhile, especially since it doesn’t cost much. I give it a 7/10. It’s worth checking out if you’re interested and/or enjoy pixel horror games.

Stray Cat Crossing is a short but very good and touching game, now for the story.

You play as a young lady who sees a lone little girl a cross the road, you walk over to her and ask what she is doing she tells you she ran away from home so after talking to her and giving her your Scarf you take her home. 

But she walks into her house forgetting to give you your Scarf back, so you must go into her home to get it.

As I have said this game is short but very good, the whole game has a dark fairy tale feel to it, from the art to the story to the Characters. 

But it’s all so really touching too. The music was good, and really liked the atmosphere was creepy and good.
Now there is not really anything bad about the game, well maybe it’s a bit to short and the ending can be a bit confusing, but that’s not really bad truth be told.

So all in all this is a really good game and at $2.99 it’s a steal, so if you want a dark fairy tale like game this one is for you.
